references: We summarize our main results below.
We derive tighter convergence rates for
Â than previously known for convex and non-convex functions with client sampling and heterogeneous data.
We give matching lower bounds to prove that even with no client sampling and full batch gradients,
Â can be slower than SGD due to client-drift.
We propose a new Stochastic Controlled AveragingÂ algorithm (
) which corrects for this client-drift. We prove that
Â is at least as fast as SGD and converges for arbitrarily heterogeneous data.
Â can additionally take advantage of similarity between the clients to further reduce the communication required, proving the advantage of taking local steps over large-batch SGD for the first time.
Â is relatively unaffected by the client sampling obtaining variance reduced rates, making it especially suitable for federated learning.
Finally, we confirm our theoretical results on simulated and real datasets (extended MNIST by

references:
Related work. For identical clients, FedAvgÂ coincides with
parallel SGD analyzed by (Zinkevich etÂ al., 2010) who proved asymptotic convergence. Stich (2018) and, more
recently Stich & Karimireddy (2019); Patel & Dieuleveut (2019); Khaled etÂ al. (2020),
gave a sharper analysis of the same method, under the name of local
SGD, also for identical functions. However, there still remains a gap
between their upper bounds and the lower bound of
Woodworth etÂ al. (2018). The analysis of FedAvgÂ for heterogeneous clients is more delicate
due to the afore-mentioned client-drift, first empirically observed by Zhao etÂ al. (2018). Several
analyses bound this drift by assuming bounded gradients
(Wang etÂ al., 2019; Yu etÂ al., 2019), or view it as additional noise
(Khaled etÂ al., 2020), or assume that the client optima are Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-close (Li etÂ al., 2018; Haddadpour & Mahdavi, 2019). In a concurrent work, (Liang etÂ al., 2019) propose to use variance reduction to deal with client heterogeneity but still show rates slower than SGD and do not support client sampling.
Our method SCAFFOLDÂ can also be seen as an improved version of the distributed optimization algorithm DANE by (Shamir etÂ al., 2014), where a fixed number of
(stochastic) gradient steps are used in place of a proximal point update. A more in-depth discussion of related work is given in AppendixÂ A. We summarize the complexities of different methods for heterogeneous clients in TableÂ 2.

For identical clients, FedAvgÂ coincides with
parallel SGD analyzed by (Zinkevich etÂ al., 2010) who proved asymptotic convergence. Stich (2018) and, more
recently Stich & Karimireddy (2019); Patel & Dieuleveut (2019); Khaled etÂ al. (2020),
gave a sharper analysis of the same method, under the name of local
SGD, also for identical functions. However, there still remains a gap
between their upper bounds and the lower bound of
Woodworth etÂ al. (2018). The analysis of FedAvgÂ for heterogeneous clients is more delicate
due to the afore-mentioned client-drift, first empirically observed by Zhao etÂ al. (2018). Several
analyses bound this drift by assuming bounded gradients
(Wang etÂ al., 2019; Yu etÂ al., 2019), or view it as additional noise
(Khaled etÂ al., 2020), or assume that the client optima are Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-close (Li etÂ al., 2018; Haddadpour & Mahdavi, 2019). In a concurrent work, (Liang etÂ al., 2019) propose to use variance reduction to deal with client heterogeneity but still show rates slower than SGD. We summarize the communication complexities of different methods for heterogeneous clients in TableÂ 2.

S7.T3.caption: Table 3: Communication rounds to reach 0.50.50.5 test accuracy for logistic regression on EMNISTÂ as we vary number of epochs. 1k+ indicates 0.5 accuracy was not reached even after 1k rounds, and similarly an arrowhead indicates that the barplot extends beyond the table. 1 epoch for local update methods corresponds to 5 local steps (0.2 batch size), and 20% of clients are sampled each round. We fix Î¼=1ğœ‡1\mu=1 for FedProxÂ and use variant (ii) for SCAFFOLDÂ to ensure all methods are comparable. Across all parameters (epochs and similarity), SCAFFOLDÂ is the fastest method. When similarity is 0 (sorted data), FedAvgÂ consistently gets worse as we increase the number of epochs, quickly becoming slower than SGD. SCAFFOLDÂ initially gets worse and later stabilizes, but is always at least as fast as SGD. As similarity increases (i.e. data is more shuffled), both FedAvgÂ and SCAFFOLDÂ significantly outperform SGD though SCAFFOLDÂ is still better than FedAvg. Further, with higher similarity, both methods benefit from increasing number of epochs.
references: We run extensive experiments on the EMNISTÂ dataset to measure the interplay between the algorithm, number of epochs (local updates), number of participating clients, and the client similarity. TableÂ 3 measures the benefit (or harm) of using more local steps, TableÂ 4 studies the resilience to client sampling, and TableÂ 5 reports preliminary results on neural networks. We are mainly concerned with minimizing the number of communication rounds. We observe that

S7.T4.caption: Table 4: Communication rounds to reach 0.45 test accuracy for logistic regression on EMNISTÂ as we vary the number of sampled clients. Number of epochs is kept fixed to 5. SCAFFOLDÂ is consistently faster than FedAvg. As we decrease the number of clients sampled in each round, the increase in number of rounds is sub-linear. This slow-down is better for more similar clients.

S7.T5.caption: Table 5: Best test accuracy after 1k rounds with 2-layer fully connected neural network (non-convex) on EMNISTÂ trained with 5 epochs per round (25 steps) for the local methods, and 20% of clients sampled each round. SCAFFOLDÂ has the best accuracy and SGD has the least. SCAFFOLDÂ again outperforms other methods. SGD is unaffected by similarity, whereas the local methods improve with client similarity.
